title: fix: `User` and `Workspace` to maintain `Argilla` as `__client` instead of `ArgillaSingleton.get()`
body:
# Description

As of the recent suggestions/recommendations from @frascuchon, using the `ArgillaSingleton` to get information from the active session is discouraged, because we may switch between sessions and the information of a session may be relative to a `User` and/or `Workspace` instance. So on, now both `User` and `Workspace` classes maintain both the `Argilla` and `httpx.Client` used initially, while the `allowed_for_roles` Python decorator is re-using those if available.

Disclaimer: we may iterate over this in future releases to avoid keeping the whole `Argilla`, but just a reduced version of it with the information we may need (for the moment we're just using `user.role` to see the role of the active user of that session).

**Type of change**

- [X] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [X] Refactor (change restructuring the codebase without changing functionality)
- [X] Improvement (change adding some improvement to an existing functionality)

title: feat: update create suggestion endpoint to `PUT`

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

labels.name: area: api
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the Fast API server or REST endpoints

body:
# Description

This PR updates the `POST` create suggestion endpoint added in #3304 to be a `PUT` endpoint instead that allows creating a suggestion for a given combination of question + record (if it doesn't exist) or update an existing one:

- The endpoint will return a `201` when the suggestion is created
- The endpoint will return a `200` when the suggestion existed and it has been updated.

Also, this PR updates the `Suggestion` SQLAlchemy ORM model adding a new unique constraint for record id and question id. As the migration file added in #3304 to create the `suggestions` table has not been applied yet in any prod environment, just in `dev.argilla.io`, I modified the migration file to include this unique constraint. Before deploying these changes in `dev.argilla.io` we will need to:

1. Revert the migration
2. Apply the latest migration

**Type of change**

- [x] Breaking change

title: [INTEGRATION] Add liveness check in `ArgillaCallbackHandler` before pushing records to Argilla

labels.name: type: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

labels.name: type: integration
labels.description: Indicates integrations with third parties

labels.name: team: ml
labels.description: Indicates that the issue or pull request is owned by the Machine Learning (ML) team

body:
**Describe the bug**

As reported by Mohamad Al Sayed in the Slack Community channel at https://rubrixworkspace.slack.com/archives/C02G2TZFG3V/p1688648005392819, the `ArgillaCallbackHandler` in LangChain is missing a liveness check to make sure that the server is up and running. So on, we should add a probe to make sure everything's up and running before trying to push anything into Argilla.

**Expected behaviour**

`ArgillaCallbackHandler` shouldn't fail if Argilla is down, but raise an exception instead or display an error message. We still need to figure 

**Environment:**
 - Argilla Version [e.g. 1.0.0]: N/A

**Additional context**

We should probably create an issue at https://github.com/hwchase17/langchain/issues to report the issue and solve it with a PR on top of it.

title: fix: `HuggingFaceDatasetMixIn` dependencies and usage

labels.name: type: dependencies
labels.description: Indicates a pull request that updates a dependency file

body:
# Description

This PR fixes some issues recently found in the `HuggingFaceDatasetMixIn` as described below:

* Records with more than one response with an empty `user_id` i.e. `user_id=None` could be pushed to the HuggingFace Hub, and when pulling it we were assuming that all the users had a valid `user_id`, so now we are just keeping the first `user_id=None` for each question, joining them and discarding the rest
* `HuggingFaceDatasetMixIn` dependencies were being imported in the top of the file, which was leading to conflicts, as `datasets` and `huggingface_hub` are optional dependencies, and as the `HuggingFaceDatasetMixIn` was being used as part of `FeedbackDataset`, an `ImportError` was being automatically raised if `datasets` and/or `huggingface_hub` were not installed, even though those were not used
* `HuggingFaceDatasetMixIn` is now properly used, without defining wrapping methods, and directly using the methods defined in the MixIn itself
* Add `Config` to manage the configuration for the available integrations (for the moment just HuggingFace), and check the dependencies once, not on every function call (similar approach to what 🤗`datasets` does)

**Type of change**

- [X] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [X] Improvement (change adding some improvement to an existing functionality)

**How Has This Been Tested**

- [X] Add unit tests to catch the warnings raised, and to make sure everything's working as expected

N.A.

title: feat: add `suggestions` in `FeedbackRecord`

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

body:
# Description

As of the recent addition of the `suggestions` in the Argilla API at https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/issues/3277, we make sure that's covered in both the SDK and the Python client.

So on, this PR adds the following:

* `suggestions` included in `FeedbackRecord`
* Update `FeedbackRecord` to "listen" for updates (for the moment just applies to `suggestions`, but may eventually be extended to `external_id`, `metadata`, and `responses`)
* Add `add_suggestions` function in the SDK
* Add `include=responses` and `include=suggestions` as default in `get_records`
* `add_question` and `add_field` now return the schema, `QuestionSchema` and `FieldSchema`, respectively (to get the Argilla ID of those, required to log `suggestions` as we use the Argilla Question ID)
* Extend `pydantic.BaseModel`s to add the `id` attribute for anything Argilla-related
* Constrain `pydantic.BaseModel`s to disallow extra fields and have more control over those
* Handle `suggestions` on both pull and push from Argilla
* Handle `suggestions` on both pull and push from HuggingFace

Additionally, I've also included some missing type-hints, improved `question_by_name` and `field_by_name` methods, fix some return type-hints, rename "`FeedbackTask` dataset" occurrences to "`FeedbackDataset`", and some other minor fixes.

Closes https://github.com/argilla-io/Team/issues/115

**Type of change**

- [X] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)

**How Has This Been Tested**

- [X] Add unit tests for the newly included `suggestions` attribute in `FeedbackRecord`
- [X] Add unit tests for the `add_suggestions` function in the SDK
- [X] Add unit tests for `FeedbackDataset.records` related functions/methods

title: [FEATURE] Upgrade to `pydantic>=2.0.0`

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

labels.name: team: ml
labels.description: Indicates that the issue or pull request is owned by the Machine Learning (ML) team

body:
Pydantic V2 has been released recently. It brings with a lot of changes in its core, mainly that it has been rewritten to Rust which makes it much much faster (between 5x - 50x faster).

We're using `pydantic.BaseModel` pretty much everywhere... The `FeedbackRecord` is a `pydantic.BaseModel`. One `FeedbackDataset` can have more than 1000 records easily, so I think we would be able to see some performance improvement once we update to `pydantic>=2.0`

Thing to take into consideration:

1. Many methods names of the `BaseModel` class have been changed. There is a v1 to v2 migration guide https://docs.pydantic.dev/latest/migration/ and also a tool https://github.com/pydantic/bump-pydantic to help with it.
2. If we update to `pydantic>=2.0`, then we need to update the API to use `fastapi>=0.100.0` which is the release that comes with `pydantic>=2.0` support.

title: [FEATURE] Add Python decorator to check `role`

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

All the functions/methods related to Argilla are exposed equally to any user no matter what role they have, and we need some sort of control to avoid sending requests to Argilla if we know that an user with that role has no access in advance. Kudos to @nataliaElv for mentioning the issue that led to the proposal of this idea.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

Ideally, we should have a Python decorator that checks for the current user's role (`admin`, `owner` or `annotator` as of Argilla 1.13.0), and raise an exception if an user is trying to perform an operation that it's not allowed to via the Python client, e.g. an annotator wants to list all the users in Argilla.

**Additional context**

This feature is also nice to internally know which users have access to what, as otherwise the Python client ends up being a little bit messy and we lose control of the permission levels.

title: [FEATURE] Allow assigning `FeedbackDataset` records to specific annotators

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

labels.name: team: interns
labels.description: Indicates that the issue or pull request is owned by the machine learning interns team

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Records cannot be assigned to specific annotators. This makes a bit hard to distribute the annotation workload between several users, needing to create several datasets and assigning one dataset to each annotator.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
I would like to be able to assign a record from a `FeedbackDataset` to a list of annotators. This would allow distributing the workload more easily between the annotators, without having to create extra `FeedbackDataset`s.

Additionally, I would like Argilla to provide some functionality to assign the records automatically to the annotators of a workspace. Some cases that I and @nataliaElv thought of:

1. If my dataset has N records and I have X annotators, then each annotator will have N / X records assigned (without overlap).
2. I would like this record to have at least N responses. If one annotator discard the record, then it would be assigned to another annotator to try to fulfil the at least N responses requirement.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Until now, the way to distribute the workload between annotators was to create N `FeedbackDataset` each with a set of records of the original dataset.

title: [FEATURE] Add conversation support to Feedback

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

labels.name: type: community request
labels.description: Indicates a feature requested by someone outside of the Argilla organization

labels.name: type: popular request
labels.description: Indicates that several people outside of the Argilla organization are interested in this feature

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
It is not clear how to use Feedback scheme to store multi-turn conversation.  It doesn't look like there is support in the web interface to annotate feedback for multi-turn conversations. A lot of Instruction Tuning data is multi-turn and the Feedback scheme only allows to record feedback to a single response.  Other schemes (i.e. Text2Text) also seem to not be suitable.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Native support for multi-turn, allowing to annotate feedback for each turn of the conversation.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Getting feedback on each turn individually and then providing context (full conversation) for each turn.  This is not great, as this results in the need to re-read each conversation N times, where N is the number of turns.  Slowing down the progress substantially.

Alternative is storing the complete conversation as text. And using the external tool, like Gradio to annotate.  This diminishes the value of Argilla, as it requires to add external/not integrated tool, disconnected from search / etc.  Storing the conversation as text, instead of structured data also reduces the ability to filter the conversation in the structured way (i.e. by last response).  Alternative is storing the complete conversation as a .json field.  This is also not great, as nearly all tooling of argilla do not have any support for this.

**Additional context**
Ideally this should be natively supported in the web UI.  But this may be implemented using a tool/plugin outside the current web/gui.  Using Gradio/Chat as a frontend may be a good option.  But either way, this still requires support at the schema level.

title: refactor: add `HuggingFaceDatasetMixIn` under `integrations`
body:
# Description

To avoid the increasing size of `argilla/client/feedback/dataset.py`, I've decided to detach the integrations from the `FeedbackDataset` class and create a MixIn class to contain all those methods specific to the integrations within the `FeedbackDataset`, in this case for 🤗 `Datasets`.

Besides that, I've also renamed the `FeedbackDatasetConfig` to `DatasetConfig`, and included some methods to dump a YAML file from now on, instead of a JSON file, since the YAML file is more readable. So now we upload `argilla.yaml` when pushing a `FeedbackDataset` to the HuggingFace Hub via `push_to_huggingface`.

I would like to see support for the https://huggingface.co/tasks/summarization task. 

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Ideally, this task should take an input and output text field.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
N.A.

**Additional context**
Each task should have a defined [task mapping schema](https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/blob/develop/src/argilla/client/feedback/training/schemas.py) and a defined representation in their associated [framework](https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/tree/develop/src/argilla/client/feedback/training/frameworks).

title: [FEATURE] add `sentence-similarity` support to the `ArgillaTrainer`

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

labels.name: area: trainer
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the Argilla Trainer

body:
<!--  Ask David for help you to contribute https://calendly.com/argilla-office-hours/30min or feel free to submit a pull request straight away: https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/pulls If you'd like to discuss your feature request or specific needs with our product team, contact Natalia Elvira in our slack community or book a slot with her: https://calendly.com/natalia-elvira/30min -->

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
The ArgillaTrainer defined in the [docs](https://docs.argilla.io/en/latest/guides/llms/practical_guides/fine_tune.html), can be aligned with the common tasks described by HF, and some of them are missing.
I would like to see support for the https://huggingface.co/tasks/sentence-similarity task.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
We want to have a workflow like shown underneath
```python
from argilla.feedback import ArgillaTrainer, FeedbackDataset, TrainingTask

dataset = FeedbackDataset.from_huggingface(
    repo_id="argilla/emotion"
)
task = TrainingTask.for_sentence_similarity(callable)
trainer = ArgillaTrainer(
    dataset=dataset,
    task=task,
    framework="sentence-transformers"
)
trainer.update_config(num_iterations=1)
trainer.predict("This is awesome!")
```

This means we should define:

- `src/argilla/client/feedback/training/schemas.py` should implement a `TrainingTaskForSentenceSimilarity` that can be initialized by a class-method `TrainingTask.for_sentence_similarity`. This `TrainingTask.for_sentence_similarity`-function should take a callable`formatting_func` which return a `str-str` `sentence-sentence`pair. 
- Passing `TrainingTaskForSentenceSimilarity` to the `ArgillaTrainer` should initiate a workflow for a training process for sentence similarity, which can either rely on a [bi-encoder](https://www.sbert.net/examples/training/sts/README.html) or [cross-encoder](https://www.sbert.net/docs/pretrained_cross-encoders.html).
-`src/argilla/client/feedback/training/frameworks/sentence_transformers.py` needs to be created with a `SentenceTransformersArgillaTrainer` that implements [the logic of fine-tuning](https://huggingface.co/blog/how-to-train-sentence-transformers).
- `tests/integration/client/feedback/training/test_sentence_transformers.py` should hold corresponding functionality tests.
- `docs/_source/_common/tabs/train_update_config.md` update the corresponding config.
- `docs/_source/guides/llms/practical_guides/fine_tune.md`update the docs with a section.

A comparable example can be found here: https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/pull/3668

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
N.A.

**Additional context**
Each task should have a defined [task mapping schema](https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/blob/develop/src/argilla/client/feedback/training/schemas.py) and a defined representation in their associated [framework](https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/tree/develop/src/argilla/client/feedback/training/frameworks).

title: fix: unit test failing if not local db

labels.name: type: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
# Description

The API startup event was using the `argilla.server.database.get_async_db` function to get a DB session to check if the default argilla user exists. We were overriding the `get_async_db` dependency for the API endpoints, but we were not mocking the function when being used from the API startup, and therefore the function was returning a session to the local sqlite DB (`$HOME/.argilla/argilla.db`). If the sqlite local db file didn't exist and the migrations hadn't been applied, then a `sqlalchemy.errors. OperationalError` was being raised as the `User` table didn't exist.

**Type of change**

title: feat: add `Suggestion` endpoints

labels.name: type: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

labels.name: area: api
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the Fast API server or REST endpoints

body:
# Description

This PR adds the following endpoints:

- `GET /api/v1/records/{record_id}/suggestions`
- `POST /api/v1/records/{record_id}/suggestions`

and updates the following ones:

- `GET /api/v1/datasets/{dataset_id}/records`: output payload updated to add suggestions depending on the value of the query parameter `include`
- `GET /api/v1/me/datasets/{dataset_id}/records`: output payload updated to add suggestions depending on the value of the query parameter `include`
- `POST /api/v1/me/datasets/{dataset_id}/records/search`: output payload updated to add suggestions depending on the value of the query parameter `include`
- `POST /api/v1/datasets/{dataset_id}/records`: input payload updated to add suggestions

Additionally and not directly related to the suggestions, this PR has updated the `GET /api/v1/me/datasets/{dataset_id}/records` endpoint to only include the responses of the record in the output payload when the value `responses` has been provided via the `include` query parameter. Old behaviour always returned the responses.

Finally, I've added a `TimestampMixin` class that can be used with a SQLAlchemy ORM model class to add the `inserted_at` and `updated_at` attributes.

Some notes about the suggestions:

- I've decided that it is a good idea to leave the `Suggestion.score` value unrestricted. At first I thought it would be good to force the user to provide a value between `0` and `1`, but users may want to assign a suggestion based on a distance based metric whose value is not bounded between `0` and `1`.
- `Suggestion.type` has only two possible values for now: `human` and `model` (machine learning, rule-based, heuristic, etc). The idea is to complement with `Suggestion.agent`.

Closes #3277

**Type of change**

- [x] Refactor
- [x] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)

**How Has This Been Tested**

Calling the endpoints in a local environment manually and adding unit tests covering all the possible cases.

title: ci: Optimize build + test pipeline
body:
<!-- Thanks for your contribution! As part of our Community Growers initiative 🌱, we're donating Justdiggit bunds in your name to reforest sub-Saharan Africa. To claim your Community Growers certificate, please contact David Berenstein in our Slack community or fill in this form https://tally.so/r/n9XrxK once your PR has been merged. -->

# Description

This PR reviews and organizes the CI pipeline. With the changes introduced here, all tests are running as expected.  

Also, the cache action has been updated in order to fix a cache resolution problem which allows to reuse the cache for the rest of the jobs.

## Two blocks of tests are launched separately 

**base tests** (most of the server tests and some basic client tests) and **extra tests** (training, monitor, listeners...). The pipeline falls into errors if resource all tests are launched in the same job. 
In the next step, those groups should be reviewed and improved.  

Refs #3291 

## Reusable jobs extraction

The job running the tests has been extracted as a separate workflow, which helps with reusability and workflow code maintenance. The same has been applied to the build Python package.

## Improve conditional executions

The `IS_DEPLOYABLE` step conditions have been removed. Now, this condition is executed just once at the related job level.
